comment_text: Flew EYW-ATL-PVD yesterday and all your staff were outstanding! The bubbly lass at gate 18 for the ATL-PVD was brilliant! Wish I remembered her name. The crew of both (FULL) flights were professional and handled passengers who didnt know where their seat was, well - time after time. Ed Bastian these folks deserve a RAISE - you should be proud of all of them!!!!! On a down side dont care much for the new airbus planes, cabin noise in places is louder than it should be and the AC control on one plane came away from its housing and could be pushed up. No biggie but detracts from the experience. Do Delta plan on adopting the European standard for cabin baggage? I wish all airlines would reduce the size of allowed cabin baggage.

I'm literally on a Delta flight that just landed in Birmingham Alabama and I want to shout out the crew!! Flight attendant Stacia and Margaret!! I have a medical condition that leaves me quite thirsty and when my throat is dry I cough and cough!! When I explained to them what my problem was, they was quick to give me a few bottles of water to get me through the flight!! Thanks guys!! It's the little things people do to make a difference!! And Thanks to the Pilots for a safe flight!!

I know it was Endeavor. We fly to Toronto a lot from Detroit to get an overseas connection. Why did you single me out of all the others who called it *Delta* even the media. It has *Delta* in huge letters on the side of the plane. If you were a news reporter and said “an Endeavor plane just crashed” 99.9% of peeps would never connect it with Delta. Now your logic is at risk.

Yes, this airplane has Delta on the side of it, along with the word Connection. It signifies that the aircraft and crew are not part of the main Delta company. You will find the crews with the more flying experience fly the mainline aircraft. Less experienced crews fly the regional jets like the one involved in this incident. This is the way it is with the larger airlines around the world. Apparently, the First Officer was flying the approach and landing into Toronto. He had about a year with Endeavor. With the weather conditions as they were, should the Captain have made the landing? As I have mentioned before, the accident board will find the main cause of the accident as pilot error and possibly lack of experience.

I was traveling on a different airline the day after the deadly crash in Washington a few weeks ago. A couple boarded late, and I suspect they had come directly from a bar. They sat directly behind me and were belligerent and foul mouthed, especially the woman, and spent 10 minutes swearing and criticizing the lead flight attendant for being a "sargeant" because she was telling people to put their seat backs up, tray tables up, and stow their backpacks under the seat for takeoff. Thankfully the flight attendant was well aware of what they were doing, and after the pilot announced a brief delay, two policemen came on the plane and removed them. Hooray! But today's crash is exactly why flight attendants enforce these safety measures. If you're in a crash and survive, you need every possible advantage to get off the plane safely. The jerks that, on occasion, still recline their seat on take off after the flight attendants have been seated could cause the people in the row behind them to die by not being able to get out of their row.

What kind of error would cause a jet to flip over on ice?
crushed landing gear on the right caused the wing to hit the ground and speed/lift on the left wing flipped the plane.

the right landing gear went thru the wing spar that held on the right wing. When the right wing separated from the aircraft, the left wing was still moving forward and producing lift. So the left wing lifted straight up in the air and rolled the entire fuselage over with it.

At a time like this, this messaging looks more like a legal maneuver than a genuine concern for transparency. A stronger, more reassuring response wouldn’t require making a distinction between Endeavor Air and Delta—it would simply acknowledge that Flight 4819 was involved in this accident, that passenger and crew safety is the top priority, and that Delta is fully cooperating with the NTSB and TSB of Canada. That’s not the same as accepting fault—it’s taking accountability for your customers, your brand, and your wholly owned subsidiary.

it is a regional carrier … commercial flight and not charter. You may feel that people are looking at negatives and that’s fine for you to start your opinion. My point is that this is not a flight that is aka a charter. This was a paid commercial flight that you book just as any other flight…. Not charter. Also if you were in the aviation industry and familiar with regional airlines, wholly own subsidiaries etc, you would understand what that person was saying. It’s a long history

What’s really worth calling out is how this is not just a single line in their statement. The CEO himself is specifically emphasizing Endeavor’s crew, making it clear that this messaging is about limiting liability first, not accountability. This isn’t just PR spin. It’s part of a larger trend where corporations are more focused on legal distancing than on doing what’s right. They aren’t trying to create warm, fuzzy reassurance for the public. If that were the case, they wouldn’t be going out of their way to make these distinctions. At some point, we need to call this out for what it is—corporate crisis management that prioritizes legal protection over human decency.

you’re completely misunderstanding what a chartered flight is, and this was absolutely not one. A charter flight is when an entity—like a corporation, sports team, or private group—leases an entire aircraft for a specific route, outside of a scheduled commercial airline operation. Those flights operate under a different certification (Part 135 or Part 380 for large charters), not standard commercial airline regulations.
You literally wrote one paragraph about the situation and then 4 paragraphs of complaining. Learn to see the glass half full and stop tainting this earth with your negative thoughts.

it doesn't matter what's said or how it's stated. Liability is Liability. And whomever is at fault will either settle or be a defendant.

evidently you’re not familiar with aviation or DOT regulations but when passengers purchase tickets on a regional carrier such as this flight, it has to be stated to them legally or in writing if booking online that the flight it marketed by Delta Air Lines but operated by Endeavor Airlines.
yep they are. I just had to take one a few weeks ago and there is a huge difference in the quality of the plane vs an actual delta flight.

I never said otherwise. I said they don’t purchase a separate ticket or go to a regional carriers website. The average consumer doesn’t analyze airline ownership structures or DOT fine print. They see Delta Connection, American Eagle, or United Express and assume they’re flying with the airline they booked. Endeavor Air operated this flight under its own Part 121 certificate, making it the first on the legal hook, but that doesn’t erase the fact that Delta owns Endeavor, sets its safety and operational standards, and markets these flights as part of its network.

Karen, this isn’t just my opinion—it’s a well-documented reality in the industry. The vast majority of passengers don’t differentiate between mainline and regional carriers because airlines market these flights under their own brand. Emergency and instead of the agents pulling the guest off of the flight immediately, Delta personnel made the decision to hold everyone over with no mention of what was happening until 45 minutes afterwards. However, after waiting and going back and forth for about an hour, the service rep across from b19 tried to assist with a room booking, but when we attempted to open the voucher we were given, we discovered it was null and void once we tried to check in and we had to now go back to the service/ ticketing desk in the baggage claim area of the airport this time. The agents there had us wait another hour and a half as they debated about the person in the b concourse, how they were ready to get off, someone having the ability to fix it but not wanting to do so, how the medical emergency wasn’t logged in their system, how they didn’t want to go behind what someone else’s work, whether they could give a paper or digital voucher, if they were going to give us one at all, shift duties, etc. Trying not to show my frustration with their conversation I continued to practice patience as my flight had landed around 840pm and it was close to midnight. A supervisor named Vonda finally cleared the hotel. However, when arriving to the airport in the morning we were still faced with the dilemma of getting our alcohol purchase through TSA, so I called customer service on the way back to the airport and explained, the customer service rep over the phone stated that we should be able to have a “red jacket” or supervisor walk us through TSA, but that was not the case. When we got to the service desk this time we were told we would have to purchase another bag/ luggage to put the alcohol items inside of at 7am…and then check the bag in or have our bags pulled so that we could put our items inside and recheck those bags in all with the possibility of missing another flight. With no time to go purchase luggage we chose the second option sprinting through the airport to get it done. Once we had our bags pulled we had to wait in another line to check them in again which took up a good amount of time, but after a long night and morning we were just happy to be home. However, this of course caused me to miss work and a job interview with little to easement besides it wasn’t Delta Air Lines fault. I said that to say a lot of the workers in the Atlanta airport seemed to need training and updates on procedures on what to do in these situations. I don’t think I’ll be flying with them again!

Our connections were missed, and instead of having sympathy or care for our situation the first two Delta agents we had to speak to literally yelled at us and told us there was nothing they could do to help us because the only flights available for four days were first class and under no circumstances do they offer rebookings as upgrades. They shooed us away to go pick up a desk phone to “get someone else to help” because there was nothing onsite Delta agents could do. We LITERALLY had to sit in the cold, depressing customer service lounge on the phone for four hours to find an option. The BEST option we were given was to take 5 flights to eventually reach our destination. I’m optimistic so I agreed. After two days of travel we arrived despite being humiliated that our connecting flights sky club lounge doesn’t accept stamped boarding passes any longer to honor 24 hour access. Then we arrived to our destination only to find that we will spend ANOTHER day without our clothes.

We felt that Delta’s getting rid of MQMs was a bad move (especially for us as foreign members), but when they ended the roll over, that was even worse. Even with the horrible changes to MQDs over MQMs we would still return to premium status with our next flight to NY this new year. Imagine our surprise when we realized that Mr. Bastian had removed the rollover piece of the SkyMiles program as well. Let us ask you, what demonstrates more loyalty than longevity. The fact that we’ve been flying Delta and SkyTeam consistently for more than a decade demonstrates loyalty. Rolling over the MQDs is a way of rewarding continued flying and increasing retention. If you reset status every year without considering what’s been given in the past, it means more ‘What have you done for me lately?’ That’s a question to ask of someone working for you, not someone being loyal to you, someone that you’re working for. On top of all that, it doesn’t make any sense to anyone. We all know that getting new customers is far more expensive than retaining loyal ones, especially your shareholders.
